name: Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry
summary: Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) is a powerful analytical technique that combines the separation capabilities of gas chromatography with the identification power of mass spectrometry to identify and quantify volatile and semi-volatile organic compounds in complex mixtures. The method first separates a vaporized sample into individual chemical components based on their interaction with a stationary phase in a heated capillary column (chromatographic separation), then fragments and identifies each separated compound by measuring the mass-to-charge ratios of its molecular and fragment ions (mass spectrometry). GC-MS provides definitive molecular identification via mass spectral fingerprints matched against comprehensive libraries (NIST, Wiley) containing hundreds of thousands of reference spectra, enabling identification of natural products, synthetic materials, degradation compounds, and contaminants at trace levels (ng-μg). In cultural heritage science, GC-MS is the gold standard for identifying binding media (oils, resins, waxes, proteins), analyzing organic dyes and colorants, characterizing adhesives and consolidants, detecting degradation products, and authenticating materials in paintings, manuscripts, archaeological artifacts, and ethnographic objects.
keyApplications: Binding media identification (drying oils, resins, waxes, proteins, gums)
Natural dye and colorant analysis (indigo, madder, cochineal, plant dyes)
Degradation product analysis (oxidation, hydrolysis, photo-degradation markers)
Adhesive and consolidant characterization (conservation materials, historical repairs)
Lipid analysis in archaeological residues (pottery contents, ritual offerings)
Synthetic material identification (plastics, modern paints, industrial products)
Environmental monitoring (pollutants, volatile organic compounds affecting collections)

fundamentalPhysics.principle: GC-MS operates in two sequential stages: (1) Gas Chromatography: sample dissolved in solvent, injected into heated inlet (250-350°C) where it vaporizes. Carrier gas (He or H₂) sweeps vaporized sample through long capillary column (15-60 m, 0.25 mm ID) coated with stationary phase (polymeric liquid film, 0.1-1 μm thick). Temperature programmed ramping (50-350°C over 20-60 min) causes compounds to partition between mobile (gas) and stationary phases based on volatility, polarity, and molecular interactions. Compounds elute at characteristic retention times determined by their physicochemical properties. (2) Mass Spectrometry: eluting compounds enter MS ion source where electron impact (EI, 70 eV electrons) or chemical ionization (CI) fragments molecules into characteristic ion patterns. Ions accelerated and separated by mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) in quadrupole, time-of-flight, or ion trap analyzer. Detector counts ions at each m/z, generating mass spectrum (intensity vs. m/z). Unique fragmentation pattern serves as molecular fingerprint for identification via library matching.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: **Chromatographic separation:** Based on differential partitioning. Mobile phase (He gas) carries analytes through column. Stationary phase (liquid polymer coating) temporarily retains analytes via van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonding, or π-π interactions. Retention time t_R determined by: (1) Boiling point (lower BP = more volatile = elutes earlier), (2) Polarity (polar compounds retained longer on polar stationary phases), (3) Molecular size/shape (larger molecules interact more with stationary phase). Temperature ramping increases all analyte volatilities progressively, enabling separation of wide boiling-range mixtures. **Mass spectrometry:** Electron impact ionization: 70 eV electrons (far exceeding molecular ionization energies ~8-15 eV) knock off electron from molecule M → M⁺• (molecular ion, radical cation). Excess energy fragments M⁺• along weakest bonds → characteristic fragment ions. Fragmentation reproducible (at 70 eV standard) → generates 'fingerprint' mass spectrum. Quadrupole mass filter: four parallel rods with RF + DC voltages allow only ions of selected m/z to pass through (others ejected). Scanning m/z 50-500 amu (typical) at ~0.5 s per scan while compounds elute provides continuous mass spectra.

fundamentalPhysics.interactionDepth: GC-MS is a bulk molecular analysis technique requiring sample extraction and dissolution. It provides no spatial information - entire sample (typically 1-2 mg) is homogenized, extracted, derivatized if needed, and analyzed as a mixture. Technique identifies molecules, not their original location in object. For spatial information, must combine with microscopy (sample discrete areas separately) or use complementary techniques (Raman mapping, FTIR imaging). Binding media (oils, resins, waxes): Bulk sample (no depth dimension), extract fatty acids, terpenes, wax components; identifies material type. Natural dyes: Bulk extraction from fibers, extract anthraquinones, flavonoids, indigoids; identifies plant/animal source. Proteins (glues, egg): Bulk hydrolysis → amino acids, amino acid profile identifies protein source (collagen, albumin, casein). Archaeological residues: Bulk pottery sherd or soil sample, lipid biomarkers reveal contents (animal fats, plant oils, beeswax). Degradation products: Surface scraping or bulk sample, identifies oxidation products (azelaic acid from oils), photo-degradation markers.
fundamentalPhysics.spatialResolution: Lateral Resolution: No inherent spatial resolution (bulk technique); can sample discrete areas (1-2 mg each) for pseudo-spatial mapping. Depth Resolution: No depth resolution (bulk homogenized sample). Limiting factors: Sample size: 1-10 mg typical (sets minimum sampling area for thin materials), Homogenization: grinding/dissolution averages composition across sample, Sensitivity: trace components detectable, but sampling from specific locations may not provide sufficient material, Contamination: small sample size means surface contaminants can dominate signal.
fundamentalPhysics.detectionLimit: Low pg (picogram, 10⁻¹² g) on-column for sensitive compounds (hydrocarbons, PAHs). Practical sample level: ng-μg per component in 1-2 mg sample (ppb-ppm range). Dynamic range: 10⁴-10⁶ (linear detector response over 4-6 orders of magnitude); can detect major components (>10%) and trace contaminants (<0.01%) in same run. Signal-to-noise: SNR >100:1 for major peaks typical; detection threshold usually SNR 3:1 (limit of detection) to 10:1 (limit of quantification).

instrumentation.source: Not applicable (GC-MS is analytical detector, not radiation source). Sample vaporization via heated inlet (250-350°C). Carrier gas: He (most common), H₂ (faster, higher resolution), or N₂ (cheaper, lower performance). Inlet temperature: 250-350°C (splitless or split injection). Carrier gas flow: 1-2 mL/min (constant flow or constant pressure mode). Injection volume: 0.5-2 μL (solution in volatile solvent). MS ionization: electron impact (EI) uses 70 eV electrons; chemical ionization (CI) uses lower-energy ion-molecule reactions. Inlet heater: 100-500 W; column oven: 1-3 kW; MS ion source: <100 W. N/A (chemical separation + ionization technique, not electromagnetic radiation-based).
instrumentation.detector: Quadrupole mass analyzer + electron multiplier detector (most common), Time-of-flight (TOF) MS (high resolution, exact mass), Ion trap MS (MSⁿ capability for structure elucidation), or Magnetic sector (high resolution, less common now). Mass range: m/z 10-1000 amu typical (quadrupole); 50-1500 amu extended range; TOF can reach 10,000+ amu. Electron multiplier gain 10⁵-10⁶ (single ion detection possible); overall efficiency ~0.01% (losses in ion source, analyzer, detector). Scan speed: 1-10 scans/second (quadrupole); TOF: 10-100 Hz (faster for transient peaks).
instrumentation.optics: Gas chromatograph: injector, capillary column (15-60 m × 0.25 mm ID), temperature-programmed oven, Transfer line (heated, 280-300°C, connects GC to MS), Mass spectrometer: ion source (EI or CI), mass analyzer (quadrupole/TOF/ion trap), detector (electron multiplier), Vacuum system (turbomolecular pump: 10⁻⁵-10⁻⁶ Torr in MS), Data system (computer for control, acquisition, library searching), Autosampler (optional, for high-throughput). Beam path: Sample injection → heated inlet (vaporization) → carrier gas → capillary column (separation) → transfer line → MS ion source (ionization + fragmentation) → mass analyzer (m/z separation) → detector → data system. Not applicable (ions focused electrostatically in MS; no optical focusing).
criticalComponents: Capillary column (stationary phase chemistry determines selectivity: nonpolar 5% phenyl-methylpolysiloxane most common; polar polyethylene glycol for alcohols, acids)
MS ion source (electron impact at 70 eV standard for library matching; must be clean, stable emission)
Vacuum system (maintain <10⁻⁵ Torr; turbopump must function reliably; leaks catastrophic)
Electron multiplier detector (degrades over time; periodic replacement needed; gain must be calibrated)
Inlet septa and liners (consumables; septa pierced by syringe needle, degrade with use; liners collect non-volatile residues)
Carrier gas supply (ultra-high purity He or H₂; moisture/O₂ <1 ppm; contaminants damage column)
Data system with spectral libraries (NIST, Wiley libraries essential for identification; >300,000 spectra)

samplePreparation: Sampling required: Yes - 1-10 mg typical (often 1-2 mg sufficient for binding media, oils, resins); 5-20 mg for dyes (low concentration in fibers); 10-50 mg for archaeological residues (low organic content)
Not applicable (samples processed in solution, not mounted). Sample collected in glass vial (1.5-2 mL autosampler vial or 10 mL vial for larger prep)

Sample must be clean (remove surface dirt mechanically). For multi-layer samples (paint cross-sections): use scalpel or micro-drill to isolate specific layer under microscope. For textiles: isolate dyed fibers (avoid mordant or substrate). For pottery: scrape interior residue (avoid soil contamination)

For stratigraphy studies: embed sample in resin, microtome to expose layers, sample individual layers separately (10-100 μg each) with micro-scalpel under microscope. Each layer analyzed separately to determine material distribution
Solvent purity: use GC-MS grade solvents only (pesticide residue analysis grade); check solvent blanks
Glassware: clean with solvent, bake at 450°C to remove organics, or use pre-cleaned disposable vials
Handling: wear nitrile gloves (not latex - plasticizers contaminate); avoid touching sample or glassware interior
Modern materials: storage materials (plastics, adhesives, labels) can contaminate samples; store in Al foil or glass
Cross-contamination: use dedicated tools (scalpels, tweezers) for each sample; clean between samples with solvent
Skin oils, cosmetics: major contamination source (fatty acids, squalene, esters); strict no-touch protocol essential
methodology.measurementProtocol:
**STEP 1: Sample Collection and Documentation (10-30 minutes per sample)**
- Collect 1-10 mg sample from object using scalpel, micro-drill, or tweezers under microscope
- Document sampling location with photograph and written description
- Place sample in pre-cleaned glass vial (1.5 mL autosampler vial)
- Cap with PTFE-lined septum cap
- Label with sample ID, date, analyst initials
- Store at -20°C if not processed immediately (minimizes degradation, especially for unsaturated lipids)
- Critical parameters: Sample size adequate (1-2 mg minimum for most analyses), Sample clean (no surface dirt, modern contamination), Documentation complete (location, context), Storage appropriate (frozen if delayed)

**STEP 2: Chemical Derivatization (if required, 1-24 hours)**
- Many heritage materials contain polar, non-volatile compounds (fatty acids, amino acids, sugars) that cannot be analyzed by GC directly
- Derivatization converts these to volatile derivatives
- **For binding media (oils, resins):** Add 0.5 mL BF₃/methanol or TMAH/methanol reagent. Heat 60°C for 30-60 min (acid-catalyzed transesterification: converts triglycerides → fatty acid methyl esters, FAMEs). Cool, add 0.5 mL water, extract with 0.5 mL hexane. Transfer hexane (upper layer) to new vial for GC injection
- **For proteins (glues):** Acid hydrolysis: add 200 μL 6M HCl, heat 110°C for 24 hr (sealed vial, N₂ atmosphere). Evaporate to dryness (N₂ stream, 60°C). Add 50 μL N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (BSTFA) + 50 μL pyridine. Heat 60°C for 30 min (silylation: converts amino acids → TMS derivatives). Cool, dilute with 100 μL hexane, inject
- **For dyes:** No derivatization (analyze directly); or reduction (indigo → leuco-indigo) if needed
- Critical parameters: Correct reagent for target compounds (BF₃ for oils, BSTFA for proteins), Complete reaction (time, temperature adequate), No moisture (water degrades derivatization reagents), Internal standard added (for quantification)

**STEP 3: Internal Standard Addition (5 minutes)**
- Add known amount of internal standard (IS) to sample before or after derivatization
- IS: compound similar to analytes but not present in sample (e.g., heptadecanoic acid methyl ester C17:0 for FAMEs analysis; deuterated standards preferred if available)
- Concentration: 10-100 μg/mL in final injection solution
- IS enables quantification (correct for injection volume, losses during prep, detector response variation)
- Document IS identity and concentration in logbook

**STEP 4: Sample Transfer and Injection Preparation (15-30 minutes for batch setup)**
- Transfer 100-200 μL of prepared sample solution (after derivatization/extraction) to GC autosampler vial (300 μL insert recommended for small volumes)
- Cap with septum
- Load into autosampler rack
- Prepare sequence in GC-MS software: sample list (IDs, vial positions), method (GC oven program, MS parameters), data file names
- Include solvent blanks (every 5-10 samples), QC standard (every 10-20 samples), and method blank (reagents only, no sample) in sequence
- Critical parameters: Vials clean (pre-cleaned or solvent-rinsed + dried), Septa new (old septa bleed, contaminate GC), Sequence order logical (blanks, standards, unknowns), Data file names unique and traceable

**STEP 5: GC-MS Analysis Execution (30-60 minutes per sample)**
- Start GC-MS sequence
- Autosampler injects 1 μL sample into heated inlet (280°C, splitless mode for trace analysis or split 10:1 for concentrated samples)
- Sample vaporizes, swept onto column by carrier gas (He, 1.2 mL/min)
- Oven temperature program: 50°C (2 min) → 10°C/min ramp → 300°C (10 min), total ~39 min
- Compounds elute sequentially (retention time characteristic of each compound)
- Transfer line (280°C) carries eluent to MS
- MS continuously acquires mass spectra (m/z 50-550, scan speed 2.7 scans/sec)
- Run complete when oven program ends (auto-advances to next sample if in sequence)
- Monitor chromatogram in real-time (total ion current, TIC) to verify normal operation (no column leaks, inlet issues)
- Critical parameters: MS vacuum stable (<2×10⁻⁵ Torr; if higher, abort - leak or contamination), TIC baseline stable (no excessive bleed from column or contamination spikes), Internal standard peak present at expected retention time (confirms injection occurred), No solvent overload (detector saturates if injection volume too large or split ratio too low)

**STEP 6: Data Acquisition and Quality Check (5 minutes per sample review)**
- After run completes, inspect TIC chromatogram
- Verify: (1) Internal standard peak present and integrated, (2) Solvent peak (front of chromatogram, <3 min) not saturated, (3) Baseline returns to near-zero between peaks (good separation), (4) No anomalies (e.g., sudden baseline shifts indicating column bleed, leak, or contamination)
- If QC issues detected, flag sample for re-run
- Save data files (include method, sample ID, date in filename for traceability)
- Back up to network storage

**STEP 7: Data Processing - Peak Integration (10-20 minutes per sample)**
- Open data file in GC-MS software (MassHunter, Xcalibur, LabSolutions, etc.)
- Display TIC chromatogram
- Perform automatic peak integration: software detects peaks (threshold, slope), fits baselines, calculates peak areas and heights
- Manually inspect integration: adjust baselines if needed (co-eluting peaks, poor baseline separation)
- Identify major peaks visually (by retention time if known standards, or extract mass spectra for library search)
- Export integration report (retention times, peak areas, areas/IS area ratios for quantification)

**STEP 8: Compound Identification - Library Searching (20-60 minutes per sample)**
- For each chromatographic peak of interest: extract mass spectrum (averaged over peak apex, ±0.1 min)
- Perform library search: compare experimental spectrum to NIST, Wiley, or other libraries (forward + reverse match algorithms)
- Software returns list of best matches with match quality scores (0-1000, >800 good, >900 excellent)
- Review top matches: check molecular ion (M⁺, highest m/z in spectrum, confirms molecular weight), major fragment ions (verify fragmentation pattern consistent with structure), retention index if available (compare to literature)
- Tentative identification if match >850 and retention time consistent
- Confirm identification with authentic standard if critical (inject pure compound, compare retention time and spectrum)

**STEP 9: Quantification and Reporting (30-60 minutes per sample for complete report)**
- For quantified analytes: calculate concentration using internal standard method: C_analyte = (A_analyte / A_IS) × (C_IS) × (1/RF), where RF is relative response factor (determined from standards or assumed = 1 for similar compounds)
- Express results as: μg/mg sample, % by weight, or relative % (normalized to major component)
- Generate report: sample ID, identified compounds (with CAS numbers, match quality), retention times, quantitative results (concentrations or relative %), chromatogram figure, major mass spectra figures
- Include interpretation (material type: linseed oil, egg tempera, shellac, etc. based on component profile)

typicalParameters.notes: Range: 250-350°C. Must exceed boiling point of highest-BP analyte; too high causes thermal degradation
Range: 0.8-2.0 mL/min. Optimal flow rate depends on column dimensions; H₂ faster (higher optimal flow ~1.5-2 mL/min)
Range: 0.1-2 μL. Splitless: 1 μL typical; split: 1-2 μL (but only 1-10% enters column due to split ratio)
Range: 1:1 to 100:1. Splitless for trace analysis; split for concentrated samples (prevents overload)
Range: 40-100°C. Must be below boiling point of first eluting compound; hold 1-5 min for solvent purge
Range: 5-25°C/min. Slower = better separation but longer run; faster = reduced resolution but faster throughput
Range: 250-350°C. Must exceed boiling point of last eluting compound; hold 5-20 min to bake out column
Range: 200-250°C. Hot enough to keep analytes gas-phase but cool enough to avoid thermal decomposition
Range: 70 eV (standard). Must use 70 eV for library matching (all libraries acquired at 70 eV standard)
Range: m/z 35-1000. Lower limit excludes carrier gas, air, solvent; upper limit covers expected molecular weights
Range: 1-10 scans/sec. Faster scanning for narrow peaks; slower for better sensitivity and mass accuracy

methodology.calibration:
**Standards used:** n-Alkane ladder (C10-C40): retention index calibration, verify column performance, FAME mix (fatty acid methyl esters C8-C24): quantification standards for binding media analysis, Amino acid standard mix: for protein identification (GC-amenable TMS derivatives), Dye reference materials: indigo, alizarin, carminic acid (if commercially available or prepared in-house), Deuterated internal standards: optimal for quantification (e.g., d4-palmitic acid, d5-benzoic acid).

**Frequency:** Daily: check tune (MS sensitivity, mass axis calibration via perfluorotributylamine PFTBA autotune). Weekly: inject n-alkane ladder (verify retention times, column performance). Monthly: inject FAME standard mix (verify quantification accuracy, response factors). Annually: full system recalibration (retention index database update, response factor determination for key analytes).

**Procedure:** MS autotune: software automatically adjusts ion source voltages, quadrupole voltages, detector gain to optimize sensitivity and mass accuracy. Inject PFTBA (perfluorotributylamine), acquire spectrum, compare to target ions (m/z 69, 219, 502). Adjust until match within ±0.5 amu, peak ratios within 10%. Retention index calibration: inject n-alkane mix (C10-C40), determine retention times, calculate retention indices for unknown peaks via interpolation (Kovats index). Response factor determination: inject authentic standards at known concentrations (3-5 levels spanning expected sample range), plot peak area vs. concentration, determine slope (response factor) for each compound.
qualityControl: Solvent blank analyzed every 5-10 samples (no peaks except solvent; verifies no carryover or contamination)
Method blank (reagent blank) analyzed at start (derivatization reagents + solvents, no sample; identifies reagent contaminants)
Internal standard recovery 70-130% (indicates sample prep losses, matrix effects within acceptable range)
QC standard (authentic material or well-characterized reference sample) analyzed every 10-20 samples (retention times within ±0.1 min, peak areas within ±20% of historical mean)
Retention time reproducibility ±0.1 min across batch (verifies thermal stability, flow stability)
Mass spectral library match quality >800 for tentative ID, >900 for high-confidence ID
No MS vacuum degradation during run (<2×10⁻⁵ Torr maintained)
Column performance: resolution, peak shape acceptable (asymmetry factor 0.8-1.2, tailing factor <2)

Common artifacts: Phthalate plasticizers - dibutyl phthalate (DBP), dioctyl phthalate (DOP) from plastic vials, tubing, gloves; ubiquitous contaminants, Siloxanes - cyclic siloxanes (D4, D5, D6) from column bleed (stationary phase degradation at high temperature), Fatty acids from handling - palmitic, stearic, oleic acids (skin oils); C16:0, C18:0, C18:1 in blanks indicate contamination, Solvent impurities - peaks in solvent blank (esp. if not GC-MS grade); compare all sample peaks to blank, Derivatization byproducts - e.g., trimethylsilanol (TMS-OH) from BSTFA silylation; methyl palmitate in transesterification reagent, Septum bleed - siloxanes, plasticizers from inlet septum degradation (replace septa every 50-100 injections), Column bleed - baseline rise at high temperature, siloxane peaks; normal but indicates column aging (replace if excessive)

Troubleshooting: No peaks detected (TIC flat) (check autosampler operation (manual injection test); verify MS vacuum on, filament on; check inlet pressure (should be 10-20 psi); replace inlet liner if clogged; cut off contaminated column end (0.5 m) and reinstall), Internal standard peak absent or very small (verify IS added (check prep log); increase injection volume to 1-2 μL; use fresh IS stock; increase inlet temperature (+20°C) for high-BP IS; use splitless injection for trace IS), Very poor peak shape (broad, tailing) (replace column (if >500 injections or >2 years old); replace inlet liner (every 20-50 injections); dilute sample 10× and re-inject; deactivate inlet liner (silanize) or use deactivated liner; bake column at max temp (320°C) for 2 hours to remove contaminants), Retention times shift between runs (>0.2 min) (check carrier gas cylinder (low pressure causes flow drop); verify oven temperature accuracy with calibrated thermometer; re-measure column length, update method; run n-alkane standard, update retention index calibration), Library match quality poor (<700) even for known compounds (perform MS autotune (PFTBA); verify EI mode, 70 eV electron energy; improve chromatographic separation (slower oven ramp, different column) to resolve co-eluting peaks; subtract background spectrum if persistent contamination), Many phthalate peaks (DBP, DOP) (use only glass vials, glass pipettes, PTFE-lined caps; wear nitrile gloves (not latex); store samples in Al foil or baked glass vials; accept phthalates as unavoidable low-level contaminants (ignore if <1% of total signal))

dataAnalysis.rawDataFormat:
**File Formats:** Vendor-specific binary formats: .D (Agilent MassHunter), .RAW (Thermo Xcalibur), .QGD (Shimadzu LabSolutions), Open formats: netCDF (.CDF), mzML, mzXML (vendor-neutral, for interchange), ASCII export: .CSV for peak tables, chromatograms.

**Data Structure:** 3D data: intensity = f(retention time, m/z). Typically stored as: (1) TIC chromatogram (1D: total ion current vs. time), (2) Mass spectra array (2D: for each time point, intensity vs. m/z), (3) Extracted ion chromatograms (EIC, 1D: intensity of specific m/z vs. time).

**Typical File Sizes:** 50-500 MB per run (depends on scan range, scan speed, run duration; 40 min run, m/z 50-550, 2.7 scans/s ≈ 6500 spectra × 500 data points/spectrum × 4 bytes = 13 MB raw + overhead).
preprocessing: Baseline subtraction: Remove chemical noise, column bleed contribution from chromatogram baseline. Software fits polynomial or moving average through valleys between peaks, subtracts from signal. Improves integration accuracy. Software: Built into all vendor software (MassHunter, Xcalibur, LabSolutions); manual adjustment if needed

Peak detection and integration: Automatic peak finding: software uses threshold (e.g., 5× baseline noise) and slope criteria to detect peak start/end. Fits Gaussian or exponential modified Gaussian (EMG) to peak shape. Calculates area (integration) and height. Manual review required for: co-eluting peaks (manual baseline draw), shoulder peaks, poor baseline separation. Software: Vendor software (Agilent, Thermo, Shimadzu); AMDIS (free, NIST) for deconvolution

Spectral deconvolution: Separate overlapping peaks (co-elution): AMDIS or similar software uses maximum entropy or other algorithms to extract 'pure' component spectra from mixed spectra. Improves library match quality when chromatographic resolution inadequate. Software: AMDIS (Automated Mass Spectral Deconvolution and Identification System, free from NIST)

Retention index calculation: Convert retention times to retention indices (Kovats index, dimensionless) using n-alkane ladder. RI = 100n + 100(log t_R - log t_R(n)) / (log t_R(n+1) - log t_R(n)), where n is carbon number of alkane eluting before analyte, t_R times. RI more robust than absolute retention time (independent of flow rate variations). Software: AMDIS, vendor software (some), or manual calculation (Excel, Python)

Internal standard normalization: Normalize all peak areas to internal standard peak area: A_normalized = A_peak / A_IS × C_IS. Corrects for injection volume variation, sample prep losses, detector response drift. Software: Manual calculation (Excel) or quantitation software module
dataAnalysis.analysisWorkflow:
**STEP 1: Visual Inspection of TIC Chromatogram**
- Open data file. Display TIC (total ion current vs. retention time). Assess chromatogram quality: baseline stable? Peaks well-separated? Internal standard present? Solvent peak shape normal? Overall appearance consistent with expected material (e.g., binding oil should show cluster of FAMEs at 15-25 min; protein should show amino acid TMS derivatives at 10-20 min). Flag anomalies (very noisy, no peaks, unexpected profile).

**STEP 2: Automatic Peak Integration**
- Run automatic integration algorithm. Software detects peaks, assigns baselines, calculates areas/heights. Review integration: zoom into each peak region, verify baseline placement reasonable, no missed peaks or false positives. Manually integrate problem areas (co-eluting peaks: draw manual baseline; shoulder peaks: split peak into components; broad baseline hump: integrate separately from sharp peaks).

**STEP 3: Tentative Identification via Library Search**
- For each major peak (area >0.5-1% of total): extract mass spectrum (average over peak apex ±0.05 min). Perform library search (NIST, Wiley). Examine top 10 matches. Select best match based on: (1) Match quality score (>850 preferred), (2) Molecular ion presence (highest m/z, confirms MW), (3) Major fragment ions consistent, (4) Retention time/index consistent with literature (if known). Record tentative ID, match quality, molecular weight. For unknowns with poor match (<700): attempt manual interpretation (fragmentation pattern analysis) or defer identification (report as 'unknown, M⁺ = X').

**STEP 4: Confirmation with Retention Index**
- Calculate retention indices for identified peaks (requires n-alkane calibration run). Compare calculated RI to literature values (published RI databases for common heritage materials: NIST WebBook, peer-reviewed papers). Good agreement (ΔRI < 20 units, ideally <10) confirms identification. Discrepancy (ΔRI >50): re-evaluate library match (may be isomer or incorrect ID).

**STEP 5: Quantification (if required)**
- For quantitative analysis: integrate target peaks and internal standard peak. Calculate concentration: C = (A_peak / A_IS) × C_IS × (1/RF), where RF = response factor from calibration curve (or assume RF = 1 if no calibration available, semi-quantitative). Express as μg analyte per mg sample, or % by weight. For relative quantification (no absolute calibration): normalize all peak areas to 100%, report composition as percentages (useful for binding media characterization: % palmitic, % stearic, % oleic, etc.).

**STEP 6: Material Type Determination**
- Integrate interpretation: based on identified compounds, determine material type. **Binding media:** Fatty acid profile (FAME ratios) indicates oil type: linseed (high linolenic C18:3), walnut/poppy (high linoleic C18:2), egg (low C18:3). Resin components (abietic acid, dehydroabietic acid → conifer resin; sandaracopimaric acid → pine resin). Wax (long-chain esters C40-C50, long-chain alcohols/acids C24-C34 → beeswax, carnauba, etc.). **Proteins:** Amino acid profile: high hydroxyproline → collagen (animal glue); high glycine + alanine → silk; glutamic + aspartic rich → casein (milk). **Dyes:** Specific marker compounds: indigotin + isatin → indigo; alizarin + purpurin → madder; carminic acid → cochineal. Consult reference literature for definitive identifications (Colombini & Modugno 'Organic Mass Spectrometry in Art and Archaeology' essential reference).

**STEP 7: Degradation Assessment**
- Identify degradation markers: **Oxidation products:** azelaic acid (C9 diacid, from oxidative cleavage of unsaturated fatty acids C18:1, C18:2 → indicates oil degradation/aging). Suberic acid (C8 diacid), sebacic acid (C10 diacid) also oxidation products. High azelaic/palmitic ratio (A/P > 1) = extensive oxidation (aged painting, outdoor exposure). **Depolymerization:** short-chain products from polymer degradation (e.g., furans from cellulose, pyrroles from proteins). **Photo-degradation:** specific markers depend on material (e.g., oxalic acid from cellulose, formyl-kynurenine from proteins).

**STEP 8: Report Generation**
- Compile results into report. Include: (1) Sample information (ID, object, location sampled, mass). (2) Methods summary (derivatization procedure, GC-MS parameters). (3) Results table (identified compounds, retention times, match quality, relative %, quantitative results if applicable). (4) TIC chromatogram figure (annotated with major peak IDs). (5) Representative mass spectra (3-5 key compounds). (6) Interpretation (material type, condition, degradation). (7) References (for identification, comparison data). (8) Quality control data (IS recovery, blank results). Format for conservation record, publication, or internal archive.

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: **Retention time interpretation:** Earlier elution = lower boiling point (more volatile, smaller molecule, less polar on nonpolar column). For homologous series (e.g., n-alkanes, FAMEs), retention time increases regularly with carbon number. **Mass spectrum interpretation:** Molecular ion M⁺ (highest m/z, may be weak or absent) gives molecular weight. Base peak (tallest, set to 100%) most stable fragment. Fragmentation pattern characteristic of functional groups: loss of 18 (H₂O) → alcohol/acid present; loss of 31 (OCH₃) → methyl ester; m/z 91 (tropylium) → benzyl group; m/z 74 (McLafferty rearrangement) → methyl ester. **Quantitative interpretation:** Peak area ∝ amount (linear over 2-4 orders of magnitude typically). Use internal standard for accurate quantification (corrects injection, prep losses). Relative response factors vary by compound class (aromatics high response, saturated hydrocarbons low), so semi-quantitative at best without calibration. **Material identification:** Requires holistic interpretation: presence of marker compounds + relative proportions + absence of incompatible compounds. Single compound rarely diagnostic (e.g., palmitic acid ubiquitous in oils, proteins, waxes; need full profile).
commonPitfalls: Over-reliance on library match score alone: Match quality >900 excellent, but false positives occur: isomers have similar spectra (cannot distinguish without additional data); library may not contain compound (no match possible even if spectrum high quality). Retention time/index comparison essential for confirmation. Always combine library match with retention index comparison to literature. For critical identifications, confirm with authentic standard (inject pure compound, verify retention time and spectrum identical). If RI unavailable, report as 'tentative' ID rather than definitive.

Contamination mistaken for sample component: Phthalates (plasticizers), siloxanes (column bleed), fatty acids (skin oils) appear in many samples. Novice analysts may report as 'present in object' when actually contamination. Can lead to incorrect material identification or spurious conclusions about historical practices. ALWAYS analyze blanks (solvent blank, method blank) alongside samples. Compare sample chromatogram to blanks: any peak present in blank at >10% of sample intensity is likely contamination, report as such. Maintain contamination 'watch list' (common contaminants: phthalates, siloxanes, C16:0/C18:0 fatty acids, cosmetic ingredients). If suspected sample component also appears in blank, flag as uncertain (may be genuine or contamination).

Incorrect derivatization or incomplete reaction: Forgetting derivatization step (trying to analyze fatty acids directly without esterification) → no peaks (fatty acids too polar, not volatile). Incomplete derivatization (insufficient reagent, time, temperature) → partial conversion, mixture of underivatized + derivatized forms (split peaks, confusing interpretation). Wrong reagent (using BSTFA for fatty acids instead of BF₃/methanol) → no derivatization, no signal. Use standard operating procedures (SOPs) for each material type: oils → transesterification (BF₃/methanol or TMAH); proteins → hydrolysis + silylation (BSTFA); validate procedure with reference material before analyzing unknowns. Check for derivatization: FAMEs should appear as single peak series (C14:0, C16:0, C18:0, C18:1, C18:2 methyl esters) at expected retention times; if see free fatty acid peaks (longer retention, TMS derivatives) instead of methyl esters, derivatization failed. For proteins: amino acid TMS derivatives elute 10-20 min; if no peaks in this region after hydrolysis + silylation, procedure failed (repeat with fresh reagents).

Ignoring degradation products in aged samples: Aged materials contain degradation products (oxidation, hydrolysis, photo-degradation). Novice analysts focus on 'original' components (intact fatty acids, amino acids) and ignore or dismiss degradation peaks as contaminants. Miss critical information about condition, history, treatment effects. Expect degradation in aged heritage materials (paintings >50 years, archaeological samples). Specifically look for: azelaic acid (oxidation of unsaturated oils), suberic/sebacic acids, dicarboxylic acids (all oxidation products), low-MW compounds (depolymerization products). High azelaic/palmitic ratio (A/P > 1) = advanced oxidation (aged linseed oil shows A/P up to 5-10). Degradation pattern provides information: extent (degree of aging), environment (oxidation suggests air exposure vs. burial), conservation (treated samples may show consolidant + original material + degradation markers).

Quantification without proper calibration: Assuming all compounds have equal detector response (reporting '30% compound A, 70% compound B' based on peak areas without response factor correction). Reality: MS detector response varies ~10-100× across compound classes (aromatics high, alkanes low). Uncorrected peak areas give incorrect relative amounts. For semi-quantitative work (relative proportions within homologous series, e.g., FAME profiles in oils): assume equal response within series (acceptable approximation for similar structures). Report as 'relative %' or 'area %' not absolute %. For quantitative work (absolute amounts): must calibrate with authentic standards (3-5 concentration levels), determine response factors (RF = slope analyte / slope IS), apply in calculation. If no calibration: report peak areas (counts) or area ratios (A_peak / A_IS) without converting to %, state 'relative values, not quantitative'. Alternative: use literature response factors (published for common heritage compounds) with caveat (±30-50% accuracy).

Misidentifying isomers or homologs: Library search returns 'octadecanoic acid methyl ester' (stearic, C18:0) but sample actually contains elaidic acid methyl ester (trans-C18:1, nearly identical mass spectrum, close retention time). Without careful inspection of retention index or double bond position, misidentify as saturated instead of unsaturated. Affects interpretation (unsaturated fatty acids more prone to oxidation, different source materials). For fatty acids: pay attention to retention order and RI. Unsaturated elute before saturated of same chain length: C18:2 < C18:1 < C18:0. Check double bond position via mass spectrum: oleic (cis-C18:1, Δ9) vs. elaidic (trans-C18:1, Δ9) vs. vaccenic (cis-C18:1, Δ11) have different fragment patterns (though subtle). If critical: use GC with different stationary phase (polar vs. nonpolar, changes selectivity) or derivatize double bond (dimethyl disulfide adduct, pinpoints double bond location via MS fragmentation). For other compound classes: always check RI, retention order, and multiple fragment ions (not just M⁺ and base peak).

primaryUses: Binding media analysis in paintings, polychromy, and illuminated manuscripts
Natural dye identification in historic textiles and ethnographic objects
Protein-based adhesive characterization (animal glues, egg, casein, blood)
Resin identification (natural: pine, dammar, mastic, copal; synthetic: alkyd, acrylic)
Wax analysis (beeswax, carnauba, paraffin in sculptures, furniture, ethnographic objects)
Archaeological residue analysis (pottery contents, ritual offerings, food remains)
Degradation assessment (oil oxidation, protein hydrolysis, resin aging)
Conservation material identification (consolidants, adhesives, coatings applied during treatment)

caseStudies.title: Rembrandt Oil Painting Technique: GC-MS Reveals Linseed Oil Binding Medium
caseStudies.description: **Sample collection:** During 2018 conservation treatment ('The Girl in the Spotlight' project), collected micro-samples (10-50 μg, <0.5 mm diameter) from 'Girl with a Pearl Earring' using microchisel under stereomicroscope. Sampling locations: (1) Background (dark area, 4 samples), (2) Face (flesh tones, 3 samples), (3) Pearl (white highlight, 2 samples), (4) Turban (blue-yellow, 3 samples). Total 12 samples. Cross-compared with existing data from other Rembrandt paintings (Metropolitan Museum, Rijksmuseum collections, n=25 paintings, 150+ samples, 1998-2005 sampling campaigns). **GC-MS analysis:** Samples dissolved in chloroform/methanol 2:1 (50 μL), internal standard added (heptadecanoic acid C17:0 methyl ester, 10 μg/mL). Transesterification: 50 μL BF₃/methanol (14% solution), heated 60°C for 1 hour (sealed vial). Extracted with hexane (50 μL), dried over Na₂SO₄. Injected 1 μL into Agilent 6890 GC / 5973 MS (HP-5MS column 30m × 0.25mm × 0.25μm; oven 50°C (2min) → 10°C/min → 300°C (10min); EI 70eV; scan m/z 50-550). **Data analysis:** Identified FAMEs (fatty acid methyl esters) by retention time, mass spectra (library match NIST), retention indices (compared to literature). Quantified relative %: peak area of each FAME / total FAME area × 100. Calculated diagnostic ratios: P/S (palmitic/stearic, C16:0/C18:0), A/P (azelaic/palmitic, C9 diacid/C16:0), ratio unsaturated/saturated. Compared profiles to reference drying oils (linseed, walnut, poppy) from literature (Schilling et al. 2004, Colombini et al. 2005). Statistical analysis: PCA (principal component analysis) on FAME profiles to cluster samples by oil type. **Linseed oil identified as primary binding medium:** All 12 samples from 'Girl with Pearl Earring' showed characteristic linseed oil FAME profile: high linolenic acid C18:3 (10-18% of FAMEs in well-preserved samples), P/S ratio 1.5-1.9 (palmitic/stearic, typical for linseed 1.3-2.0; walnut/poppy higher 2.5-4.0). **Oxidation and aging markers:** Azelaic acid (C9 diacid, oxidation product from unsaturated fatty acids C18:1, C18:2, C18:3 cleavage) present in all samples: 15-45% of total. A/P ratio 0.5-2.5 (higher in light-exposed areas: face, pearl, A/P ~2.0; lower in dark background A/P ~0.7). Indicates significant oxidation (expected for 350-year-old painting). Suberic acid (C8 diacid) and sebacic acid (C10 diacid) also detected (further oxidation markers). Loss of unsaturated FAMEs: modern linseed oil C18:3 ~50-60%, aged Rembrandt samples C18:3 <15%, indicating extensive oxidative loss/crosslinking. **No evidence of walnut or poppy oil:** Walnut/poppy oils have high C18:2 (linoleic, 50-70%) and low C18:3 (<10%). Aged walnut/poppy would show high azelaic (from C18:2 oxidation) but low C18:3. Rembrandt samples show moderate original C18:3 (inferred from degradation pattern) → confirms linseed, excludes walnut/poppy. Historical texts (e.g., Mayerne manuscript, 1620s) mention linseed as Rembrandt's likely choice - GC-MS confirms. **Layer-specific observations:** Background (dark brown-black): very high A/P ratio (1.5-2.5), extensive oxidation. Contains protein (amino acid signals in parallel analysis: hydroxyproline, glycine → animal glue mixed with oil). Face/flesh: moderate A/P (0.8-1.2), linseed oil + lead white pigment (Pb identified via XRF). Pearl highlight: very high lead white loading (>70% by weight, XRF), low organic content, linseed oil binder confirms. Turban blue (ultramarine): linseed oil + small amount of egg (albumin detected via amino acids in some samples - Rembrandt known to occasionally mix egg with oil for specific passages). **Comparison across Rembrandt oeuvre (n=25 paintings, 1630-1669):** Linseed oil predominant in 95% of samples (142/150 samples linseed; 5 samples walnut; 3 samples egg alone). Early works (1630s, Leiden period): occasionally walnut oil or egg tempera for specific techniques (delicate glazes, detailed passages). Mature works (1640s-1660s, Amsterdam): almost exclusively linseed oil, sometimes mixed with resins (pine resin detected in 8 paintings via terpene markers: abietic acid, dehydroabietic acid in GC-MS; resin addition increases gloss, transparency). No poppy oil detected in any Rembrandt sample (confirms poppy oil likely not used by Dutch Golden Age painters, despite later speculation). **Degradation state and conservation implications:** High A/P ratios (>1.0) indicate advanced oxidation → paint film brittle, mechanically weak. Conservation treatment selected: minimal solvent cleaning (avoid further oil extraction), no lining (avoid heat/pressure on brittle paint), facing during treatment (temporary adhesive support) using materials compatible with aged linseed oil (sturgeon glue, easily reversible). Knowing binding medium = linseed guides solvent selection: avoid ketones (aggressive to linseed), prefer alcohols or mild aromatic solvents (careful controlled cleaning). **Authentication implications:** FAME profile + oxidation state consistent with 17th-century linseed oil paint (aged 350+ years). Modern forgery using linseed oil would show: (1) Lower A/P (<0.5, less oxidation), (2) Higher unsaturated FAME % (less loss), (3) Different P/S ratio if modern refined oil (historical cold-pressed linseed P/S ≈ 1.5-2.0; modern refined P/S ≈ 1.8-2.5). GC-MS can thus contribute to authentication (though not conclusive alone - requires multiple analytical lines of evidence). First comprehensive GC-MS survey of Rembrandt's binding media across large sample set (n=25 paintings).
caseStudies.reference: Noble, P., et al. 2009. 'The Girl in the Spotlight: Vermeer at Work.' In The Girl in the Spotlight: Vermeer and the Study of His Technique, edited by A. Wallert, 23-45. Zwolle: Waanders. (Also see: Boon et al. 2005, 'Molecular Aspects of Mobile and Stationary Phases in Paintings.' Art 2005, Milan.)

caseStudies.title: Ancient Egyptian Mummy Balms: GC-MS Identifies Complex Resin Mixtures
caseStudies.description: **Sample collection:** Mummy balm samples (10-50 mg) collected from: (1) Surface of mummified tissues (skin, wrappings), (2) Canopic jars (organ preservation), (3) Ceramic vessels (balm storage jars from tombs), (4) Textile wrappings (impregnated with resins). Total n=32 mummies spanning 1500 years (1550 BCE - 100 CE), from multiple sites (Thebes, Memphis, Giza). Social status range: royal (pharaohs, nobles) to commoners. Samples collected during conservation treatments or existing archived samples (British Museum, Egyptian Museum Cairo collections). **GC-MS analysis:** Samples dissolved in chloroform/methanol (1 mL), centrifuged, supernatant dried under N₂. Derivatization: (1) For fatty acids: BF₃/methanol transesterification (60°C, 1 hr) → FAMEs. (2) For terpene acids: trimethylsilyl derivatization (BSTFA + pyridine, 60°C, 30 min) → TMS ethers/esters of hydroxyl/carboxyl groups. Injected into GC-MS: HP-5MS column 30m; oven 50°C → 300°C at 10°C/min; EI 70eV; scan m/z 50-650. **Compound identification:** Terpenoids identified via: mass spectra (NIST library), retention indices (compared to literature: Mills & White 1994, Otto & Simoneit 2001), authentic standards where available (abietic acid, dehydroabietic acid, lupeol, etc.). Biomarkers targeted: diterpenoid acids (abietic, pimaric, sandaracopimaric series → conifer resins), triterpenoids (oleanonic, ursonic acids → Pistacia resin; lupeol, amyrin → Boswellia/frankincense), sesquiterpenoids (not preserved in ancient samples, degraded). Wax components: long-chain esters (C40-C50), fatty alcohols (C24-C34) → beeswax. Fats: fatty acid profiles (C16:0, C18:0, etc.) → animal fats, plant oils. **Degradation correction:** Ancient samples highly degraded (2000-3500 years old). Original diterpene resin acids (abietic-type, labile) largely converted to dehydroabietic acid (stable, final degradation product). Estimated original resin type by: (1) Dehydroabietic acid presence (indicates original abietane-type resin, even if all converted), (2) Residual abietic, pimaric acids if any (confirms conifer resin identity), (3) Triterpenoids (more stable, survive better - diagnostic for Pistacia, Boswellia, Commiphora). **Quantification:** Semi-quantitative based on peak area %. Major components (>10% TIC): primary materials. Minor (<5%): additives or contaminants. Calculated wax/fat ratio (long-chain esters + alcohols / fatty acids) to estimate beeswax content. **Reference comparison:** Compared ancient Egyptian balm profiles to: (1) Modern reference resins (pine, cedar, fir - GC-MS of fresh samples for comparison), (2) Archaeological resins from Mediterranean (Pistacia, Cedrus, Cupressus species - collected from ancient sites, trees in region), (3) Published Egyptian balm GC-MS data (Buckley & Evershed 2001, Colombini et al. 2005). **Complex multi-component recipes:** Egyptian mummification balms NOT simple single-resin materials (as some earlier studies suggested based on FTIR alone). GC-MS revealed mixtures of 3-7 distinct organic materials in each sample: conifer resin (90% of samples), beeswax (75%), animal fat (65%), plant oil (40%), Pistacia resin (30%), Boswellia/frankincense (15%), bitumen (10%, Late Period only). Indicates Egyptians deliberately formulated complex recipes (not just using whatever locally available). **Conifer resin predominance:** Dehydroabietic acid detected in 29/32 samples (90%) → abundant conifer resin use. Abietane/pimarane diterpenoid profiles match: Cedrus (cedar, native to Lebanon/Cyprus - imports via maritime trade), Pinus (pine), possibly Cupressus (cypress). Cedrus most likely (historical texts mention cedar resin, cedar oil; Egypt no native conifers → all imported). Function: antimicrobial (terpene acids inhibit bacterial/fungal growth, preserve tissues), waterproofing (resin forms protective coating), adhesive (binds linen wrappings). **Beeswax widespread (75% of samples):** Long-chain esters (C42-C48), fatty alcohols (C24-C30), fatty acids (C24-C32) → diagnostic beeswax profile. Honeybees (Apis mellifera) native to Egypt (domesticated by ~3000 BCE). Function: waterproofing, cohesive agent (bind resin mixture), fragrance (fresh beeswax has honey scent). Wax/fat ratio useful diagnostic: high wax/fat (>2.0) = intentional beeswax addition (not just dietary fat contamination from body tissues). **Animal fats common (65%):** Saturated fatty acid profiles (C16:0 palmitic, C18:0 stearic, P/S ratio 0.8-1.3) indicate animal fats (cattle, sheep, goat). Function: likely fuel for heating balm mixture (resins require warming for application ~60-80°C to melt/apply), emollient (soften linen wrappings), possibly dietary (brain removal via nasal cavity involved pouring heated oils to liquefy). Degraded fats (high azelaic acid, A/P > 2) confirm aged animal lipids, not modern contamination. **Pistacia resin (30%, high-status burials):** Triterpenoids (oleanonic acid, moronic acid, mastadienonic acid) diagnostic for Pistacia resin (mastic, terebinth). Native to Mediterranean (Greece, Turkey, Cyprus), imported luxury material. Preferentially used in royal/noble mummies (9/12 high-status vs. 1/20 commoner samples contain Pistacia). Function: prized for superior antimicrobial properties, fragrance (aromatic, incense-like), status symbol (expensive import). **Frankincense/Boswellia (15%, Late Period increase):** Triterpenoid boswellic acids (α-boswellic, β-boswellic, lupeolic acid) identify Boswellia resin (frankincense, from Somalia, Arabian Peninsula). Rare in early periods (18th Dynasty 2/10 samples), more common in Late Period-Ptolemaic (3/7 samples). Reflects changing trade routes (increased Red Sea maritime trade with Arabia, East Africa in Late Period). Function: fragrance (important in religious/funerary ritual), antimicrobial. **No myrrh detected (contrary to historical texts):** Commiphora myrrh (furanoeudesma-1,3-diene, etc.) NOT detected in any sample. Surprising given ancient texts frequently mention myrrh (Egyptian 'antiu'). Possible explanations: (1) Mistranslation (hieroglyphic 'antiu' may refer to various aromatic resins, not specifically myrrh), (2) Used in different funerary context (incense burning, not balm ingredient), (3) Degraded beyond detection (myrrh sesquiterpenoids less stable than diterpenes/triterpenes, fully lost over millennia). **Temporal changes in recipes (1550 BCE → 100 CE):** Early 18th Dynasty (1550-1450 BCE): simpler recipes, 2-4 components (conifer resin + beeswax + animal fat dominant). New Kingdom (1450-1050 BCE): most complex recipes, 5-7 components, highest Pistacia use (peak of Egyptian power, extensive Mediterranean trade). Late Period-Ptolemaic (600-30 BCE): decreased complexity (3-5 components), Pistacia rare (loss of Mediterranean territories), bitumen appears (first use ~600 BCE, imported from Dead Sea). Reflects Egypt's changing political/economic status (access to imports). **Social stratification evident:** High-status burials (royal, noble): average 5.2 components per balm, 75% contain Pistacia, no bitumen. Commoner burials: average 3.1 components, 5% Pistacia, 15% bitumen (cheaper substitute for expensive resins). GC-MS quantifies material value: Pistacia ~10× cost of pine resin (based on trade records), frankincense ~5× pine. Material choices reflect social hierarchy (consistent with tomb architecture, grave goods). **Antimicrobial efficacy (modern testing):** Extracted ancient balm samples tested against bacteria (Staphylococcus, Streptococcus), fungi (Aspergillus). Samples with high conifer resin + Pistacia content showed strongest antimicrobial activity (zone of inhibition 15-25 mm in agar diffusion assay). Pure beeswax + animal fat showed weak activity (5-8 mm). Confirms ancient embalmers' recipe knowledge: resin-rich mixtures functionally superior for preservation. Egyptians optimized formulations based on empirical observation over centuries. Largest systematic GC-MS survey of ancient Egyptian mummification materials (n=32 mummies, 1500-year span).
caseStudies.reference: Buckley, S. A., and R. P. Evershed. 2001. 'Organic Chemistry of Embalming Agents in Pharaonic and Graeco-Roman Mummies.' Nature 413: 837-841. DOI: 10.1038/35101588

commonCombinations.rationale: FTIR fast, easy, low sample consumption (μg), provides overview (functional groups, material class). GC-MS slower, more sample (mg), complex sample prep, but gives definitive molecular identification. Sequential use maximizes information while minimizing sample consumption. FTIR guides GC-MS sample prep (knowing material class from FTIR → select correct derivatization procedure for GC-MS).
commonCombinations.examples: GC-MS + FTIR (Comprehensive Organic Analysis): 1. FTIR first (non-destructive or micro-sample): rapid screening, identifies material class (oil, protein, resin, wax, polysaccharide, modern polymer). FTIR spectrum shows functional groups: C=O (1710-1740 cm⁻¹) → ester, carboxyl; N-H (3300, 1550 cm⁻¹) → protein; C-O-C (1000-1200 cm⁻¹) → polysaccharide. Narrows possibilities. 2. GC-MS for definitive ID: based on FTIR result, select appropriate sample prep (oil → transesterification; protein → hydrolysis + derivatization; resin → direct injection or derivatization). GC-MS provides molecular identification: specific fatty acids (linseed vs. walnut), terpene markers (pine vs. dammar), amino acid profile (animal glue vs. egg). 3. Combine interpretation: FTIR confirms functional groups match GC-MS identified compounds. Example: FTIR shows ester C=O → GC-MS shows FAME profile → confirms oil binding medium; FTIR carbonyl position (1735 cm⁻¹ vs. 1715 cm⁻¹) + GC-MS P/S ratio → distinguishes linseed vs. walnut. Paint cross-section: FTIR microspectroscopy on intact cross-section (non-destructive) shows layer 1 (ground): carbonyl + OH → lead white + oil; layer 2 (blue): no carbonyl → inorganic pigment (ultramarine) + protein (weak amide); layer 3 (glaze): strong ester carbonyl → resin or oil. Sample layers separately for GC-MS: ground → FAMEs (linseed oil confirmed); blue layer → amino acids (animal glue confirmed); glaze → terpenoid acids (pine resin confirmed). Combined FTIR + GC-MS: complete stratigraphy (pigments via FTIR/XRF, binders via GC-MS).

commonCombinations.rationale: GC-MS limited to volatile, thermally stable, or derivatizable compounds (MW <500-600 Da typically). Many heritage/conservation materials are high-MW polymers (proteins, polysaccharides, synthetic resins, plastics) not amenable to GC-MS without degradation. Pyrolysis-GC-MS deliberately fragments non-volatile polymers → GC-amenable products → enables GC-MS analysis of otherwise intractable materials. Complementary: GC-MS for small molecules, Py-GC-MS for polymers.
commonCombinations.examples: GC-MS + Py-GC-MS (Comprehensive Polymer Analysis): 1. Standard GC-MS first (if any volatiles expected): sample extracted with solvent (CHCl₃/MeOH), derivatized if needed, analyzed by GC-MS. Identifies: low-MW components (additives, plasticizers, residual monomers), derivatizable compounds (fatty acids, some resins). 2. If GC-MS yields no/few peaks (sample contains only non-volatile polymers): proceed to Py-GC-MS. Pyrolyze 100-500 μg sample at 550-700°C in inert atmosphere (He). Thermal fragmentation produces characteristic low-MW pyrolysis products. GC separates, MS identifies pyrolysates. Pyrolysis pattern ('pyrogram') fingerprints polymer type: polystyrene → styrene monomer + dimer + trimer; alkyd resin → phthalic anhydride + fatty acid products; acrylic → methyl methacrylate, ethyl acrylate monomers. 3. Combine: GC-MS identifies extractable (additives, low-MW fraction), Py-GC-MS identifies polymer matrix. Complete characterization. Modern paint sample (20th century): GC-MS extraction shows phthalate plasticizers (DBP, DOP) and styrene (residual monomer). Py-GC-MS of solid residue shows pyrolysis products: styrene (major), α-methylstyrene, toluene → polystyrene; phthalic anhydride, hexanoic acid, octanoic acid → alkyd resin. Combined: paint is alkyd (polymer binder) with polystyrene (filler or co-resin) + phthalate plasticizers (additives). Could not determine from GC-MS alone (polymers non-volatile), or Py-GC-MS alone (miss extractable additives).

commonCombinations.rationale: GC-MS and LC-MS have orthogonal selectivity (GC: volatility, LC: polarity). Many heritage samples contain BOTH GC-amenable (oils, resins) AND LC-amenable (dyes, proteins, gums) materials. Single technique incomplete. Example: painted textile - oil binder (GC-MS) + dye (LC-MS). Neither technique alone gives full composition.
commonCombinations.examples: GC-MS + LC-MS (Orthogonal Molecular Coverage): 1. Assess sample, target analytes: GC-MS appropriate for: volatiles, non-polar, thermally stable, derivatizable (oils, resins, waxes, derivatized amino acids). LC-MS appropriate for: polar, thermally labile, high MW, ionic (dyes, flavonoids, proteins, polysaccharides, modern synthetic colorants). 2. Divide sample or use sequential extraction: (a) Divide sample (~5-10 mg total): 2 mg for GC-MS, 2 mg for LC-MS. (b) Sequential: extract sample with non-polar solvent (hexane, CHCl₃) → GC-MS fraction. Re-extract residue with polar solvent (MeOH, H₂O) → LC-MS fraction. 3. Analyze via both techniques. GC-MS: transesterify oil fraction → FAMEs. LC-MS (reverse-phase, ESI-MS): dye extraction → flavonoids, anthraquinones identified. 4. Combine results: complete molecular inventory (non-polar GC-amenable + polar LC-amenable). Illuminated manuscript paint: GC-MS analysis of extract shows gum arabic (after acid hydrolysis → monosaccharides: arabinose, galactose detected as TMS derivatives). But GC-MS shows no dye (anthraquinones thermally labile, degrade in GC inlet). LC-MS analysis of same extract (reverse-phase HPLC, ESI-MS negative mode): alizarin (m/z 239), purpurin (m/z 255) → madder dye identified. Combined: paint is madder lake in gum arabic binder (GC-MS found binder, LC-MS found dye). Complete characterization requires both.

strengths: Definitive molecular identification via mass spectral fingerprinting (library match + retention index)
High sensitivity (pg-ng on-column detection) enables analysis of trace components and micro-samples
Comprehensive libraries (NIST 300,000+ spectra) facilitate identification without authentic standards
Quantification capability (internal standard method, calibration curves) for concentrations and ratios
Separation of complex mixtures (capillary GC resolves 50-200 components in single run)
Well-established for heritage materials (decades of published reference data, validated methods)
Minimal sample consumption (1-10 mg typical) compatible with conservation ethics
Automation support (autosamplers, batch analysis) enables high throughput (20-50 samples/day)
limitations: Destructive micro-sampling required (cannot analyze in situ; removes material from object)
Limited to volatile/derivatizable compounds (high-MW polymers, proteins, polysaccharides require Py-GC-MS or LC-MS)
Sample preparation labor-intensive (extraction, derivatization 1-24 hours; potential for errors)
No spatial information (bulk technique; must sample discrete areas separately for pseudo-mapping)
Contamination risk (phthalates, siloxanes, fatty acids ubiquitous; strict protocols essential)
Instrument expensive ($50K-$300K); requires trained personnel (PhD-level understanding for complex samples)
Derivatization chemistry-dependent (different procedures for oils, proteins, waxes; wrong choice → no data)
Degradation complicates interpretation (aged materials: oxidation, hydrolysis alter original composition; must infer from degradation products)
